abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Municipal
            Development and Decentralization Project for Georgia were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: in absence of a
            law on local budget, signing municipal development
            agreements (MDAs) between MDF and borrowing local self
            governments (LSGs) proved to be crucial, especially when
            arrears/default occurred and some legal actions had to be
            taken. Loan portfolio management should include a receivable
            aging analysis method, whose monthly monitoring could inform
            MDF on the status of arrears. Immediate actions by MDF to
            respond to arrears and defaults are crucial. A soft stance
            may encourage other borrowers to default themselves. In the
            meantime ministry of finance should not bail out any
            defaulter. Very careful consideration should be given during
            project design to define 'realistic' cost
            recovery. Full cost recovery is impossible for several
            municipal infrastructure investments, e.g. local roads
            rehabilitation, street lighting, wastewater and drainage.
            Consideration should be given instead, in such cases, to
            efficiency and savings in operation and maintenance cost.
            Unexpected changes in the government's structure and
            policy may be an opportunity to be seized by the task team
            to improve project implementation and ensure the new
            government's commitment to ownership of the project. By
            the same token, unexpected new donors' support emerging
            during implementation could be an opportunity, but it
            requires considerable effort by the Bank team and government
            to ensure coherence o f the overall support being provided.
